Yes, the change is more invasive due to the Go SDK doing type checking manually, allowing nested KVs and making CoGBK a first-class concept (unlike both Python and Java). Some related cleanup work (BEAM-3316) and minor tweaks were also done here to end up in a better place.

CC: @robertwb @udim

Are you sure we want to re-infer the types here, as opposed to copy the types that were already present. (In particular, this will play better once we move to using coders rather than types post runner boundary, and I'm a bit wary of what will happen if different types are inferred than the first time around.)
Good point, with FlatMap we  literally replace the DoFn.process callable. Updated the PR description.

retest this please
It looks like the failures do not have to do with the branch. That makes sense since it hasn't changed in some time. It could be Jenkins script w/ pipeline options.

It turns out that all of our idea plugin config is not effective when we do not delegate, because the hints are relative to Gradle's output directories, not IntelliJ's. The comments on the linked ticket indicate how to set things up for IntelliJ in a Java-specific way so perhaps we can try for the same in all areas. I am not sure.

CC @akedin @bsidhom
CC @akedin @bsidhom FYI
See #4627 as I think the failures are legitimate.

Looking at https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/2315 it seems we should recommend using `gradle idea`. However, I want the project files to be generated outside the source tree, to support `git clean` so that is a prerequisite.

Closing this as I _don't_ think we should just ignore these, until we have them configured properly within the gradle scripts.

retest this please
Run Go Gradle PreCommit

Are they using the exact same set of output directories?
The issue with using the same output directories is that Gradle may be configured to use JDK A and Intellij to use JDK B and then when they compile their code they may produce slightly different artifacts.
See: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-175172
That youtrack issue is where I found the solution, commented in #4626. Probably the fix is to have them use the same JDK?

I'm totally open to other solutions. The issue is whether we want to have and "idea" plugin configuration that works with gradle delegation (thus needs `build` for the output dirs) or one that works for pure IntelliJ (much faster and featureful, uses `out` by default) or one that works for both.
Thanks Kenn. I'm testing before merging.

HBase tests are still failing. I'm taking a look.

There may be one issue we should talk about : When coding the digest, I used the method "asSmallBytes" which converts doubles to float and integers to short, in order to optimize memory, at the cost of approximations. 
I will change this in the next commit because I'm sure you will agree that the successive serializations during the pipeline execution might lead to a significant lose of accuracy for very large streams.
But in fact we could also give the choice to the user with another parameter, if someone want to fully optimize memory use. What do you think ?
Problem is the test methods are not isolated so the table names conflicted. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3637

@ArnaudFnr I just added a gradle build script for the sketching extension (since we don't have one). Can you please rebase your PR and add the t-digest dependency there too.
You can test if everything work as intended by doing:
```
cd sdks/java/extensions/sketching
gradle clean build
```
If everything works as intended this command will pass with no errors.
